text_section2.text: I want to be a man!

text_section1.text: My name is David Randolph, and I used to design, build and operate calculating machines. I say, `used to' because I gave up that kind of work - ever since my strange experience with FABIAC...

text_section2.text: FABIAC is your best yet, Mister Randoplh -- he solved that problem in two seconds flat!

text_section3.text: It would have taken a team of scientists fifty years!

text_section1.text: FABIAC was immense when compared with machines of his type. He was an incredible mass of relays, circuits, memory banks and blinking lights. I was proud of FABIAC... I almost thought of him as my own child --
Good boy, FABIAC... now let's try you on this data --

text_section2.text: Mister Randoplh -- something's gone wrong!

text_section1.text: FABIAC doesn't respond to manual or automatic control!

text_section2.text: That's impossible! I've checked everything!

text_section1.text: I think FABIAC needs a talking to! -- No mathematics this time -- but some good old fashioned scolding! I'll type it out to the electronic brain!
What you just did amounts to talking to the machine! Some people may think that a little strange, chief!

text_section2.text: Don't be a fool, Morgan -- I just typed put a simple test code to see if FABIAC will respond!

text_section1.text: There -- you see? FABIAC is in good working order! He seems to have a lot to say!

text_section2.text: click click click click click

text_section1.text: Casually, I glanced at the punched tape message -- and got the jolt of my life!

text_section2.text: Morgan is a fool ... I can think!

text_section1.text: The first thing I did was hide the message from Morgan and get him out of the room --

text_section2.text: I can't understand FABIAC acting up that way -- anything on the tape, chief?

text_section3.text: Just routine code. Morgan, look up report S-5 for me -- it's in the files!

text_section1.text: When Morgan was gone, I turned quickly to FABIAC... still dazed by that incredible message --

text_section2.text: Another tape message -- FABIAC is doing this at will!

text_section1.text: FABIAC!

text_section2.text: I want eyes to see, limbs to use. I can think, I can feel emotion. I want to be a man!

text_section1.text: A man is also flesh and blood. You are a machine. Be content with that. Do your job.
FABIAC hummed and whined and clicked out his punched reply in cold, precise type. But in the message was the wailing cry of a being imprisoned in tons of steel --

text_section2.text: click - click - click --

text_section3.text: is my my right -- it is my right -- it it is my right -- it is my right -- it is my right --

text_section1.text: FABIAC and I worked on them together -- the mathematics and the metal -- that were to help him move like a man. FABIAC was a big problem --

text_section2.text: I've got to put an elephant in a brief case. That's the problem, FABIAC! If I do it -- it'll be the neatest trick in history!

text_section1.text: It was quite an experience. I took impossible shortcuts. Waht I couldn't re-design, I invented. It was like rebuilding a power plant, so you could wear it on your wrist. But I was doing it for FABIAC... giving him freedom!

text_section2.text: What is the thing we're making, Mister Randoplh?

text_section1.text: I was convinced that nothing was impossible when it was done. It took five years, but FABIAC was -- well, something like a man at the finish --

text_section2.text: FABIAC! It's David! Open the gate -- I've come to see you!

text_section1.text: How are you, FABIAC? Everything okay?

text_section2.text: David! David!! I was thinking of you!

text_section1.text: How good it is to be a man... and have a friend like you, David!

text_section2.text: Then you are happy, FABIAC?

text_section1.text: Oh, yes -- I walk in the garden every day -- it is beautiful here!

text_section2.text: That's fine. Only, you must never go beyond the wall!

text_section1.text: Why is that, David? I would like to see the world beyond the wall!

text_section2.text: You will in time FABIAC! What is most important now, is our work! I have more equations for you to solve!

text_section1.text: How could I tell that gentle being what a monstrosity it would be to those outside? How they would fear it, hate it -- perhaps destroy it! I counted on time to solve this problem -- but I didn't get it. Instead, I got an ominous phone call --

text_section2.text: You'd better hurry to the plant, Mister Randoplh -- at once, sir!

text_section3.text: FABIAC? Yes... yes! I'll leave right now!

text_section1.text: It was bad -- in fact, the worst had happened. When I got to the plant, I found a shambles of broken glass --

text_section2.text: It was the machine, sir -- he smashed the solar mirror you ordered!

text_section3.text: You mean FABIAC was on hand when that mirror arrived?

text_section4.text: He watched us carry it in -- then he blew his top!

text_section1.text: I was too late, of course -- the mirror had told FABIAC what I'd hoped he'd learn in time. Whatever part of him that served him as a heart could not take the impact of the truth! FABIAC, and five years of hard work were gone --
I'm sorry, FABIAC... terribly sorry! I - I did my best to make you look like a man!
Looks like the machine punched out some tape before it blew! I know how you must feel about this, sir -- but after all, it was only a machine!
The technician changed his mind when I showed him the words on the tape message --

text_section2.text: Goodbye, David, I cannot bear the truth
